children.value: In the previous subchapters, we discussed how we acknowledge our contributors for their work in
, which are updated regularly to reflect the contribution types and personal highlights of the contributors.
In this subchapter, we will explore the different types of contributions that exist within
, and describe those with the help of the

our contributors may take to make their contributions.
Furthermore, we describe how each persona will be acknowledged in
We use the term ‚Äúbug‚Äù for small errors in the text or code like typos, formatting issues or broken links, or minor fixes.
: Fraya found a typo and fixed it.
They are acknowledged in the Contributors table with a üêõ (

: Amal has found multiple typos on multiple visits to the project and contributes to conversations in issues about where these typos cause confusion or need additional input to fix.
Amal has had a sustained engagement with the community.
Amal is acknowledged in the Contributors table with a üêõ (
) emoji and named as an author on the last 2 releases of the book.
Contributors can also provide examples that can make
: Divna made a pull request to add an example that enhanced the quality of the chapter.
: Pawel wrote a subchapter and added it through a pull request to add a detailed example that demonstrated the content of the chapter being used in a real world example.
) emoji in the Contributors table and named as an author on the last 3 releases of the book.
We encourage our contributors to write a piece of code, bots or scripts to help improve the project workflow.
Persona for writing scripts for the project
: Kendra wrote a Python script to spot a Latin word in a new contribution, which should be avoided in this book.
Persona for reusing an existing tool

They further wrote a Python script to make the error report easy to understand and fix.

Contributors can provide test data for a test or to link with a chapter to improve the overall content.

Reviewing chapters and other pull requests

children.label: Reviewing chapters and other pull requests

children.value: The review process of a newly contributed chapter or a subsection of an existing chapter involves approving the language and structure of a chapter or a section of a chapter, flagging errors or typos, asking for clarifications if certain parts of the content or statements are unclear, suggesting modifications and improving the overall quality of someone‚Äôs contribution.
Persona for reviewing one pull request

: Tashan has reviewed a pull request that contributed one additional paragraph to an already existing chapter.
They approved the pull request after catching two typos and giving a suggestion for a clearer phrasing of one sentence.
They are acknowledged in the Contributors table with the üëÄ (
Persona for reviewing pull request over sustained engagement

: Sadaf has reviewed a new chapter on ‚ÄúSecure communication for distributed teams‚Äù.
She gave comprehensive feedback on the structure of the proposed references and suggested a new format.
She was engaged for multiple reviews of the same pull request and engaged closely with the community member who wrote the chapter.
Sadaf is acknowledged in the Contributors table with the üëÄ (
) emojis, and she is named as an author on the latest release of the book.
The various contributions to a chapter are made towards designing, writing, and reviewing its content through GitHub issues, pull requests and reviewing processes.

: Jordon has written a chapter on ‚ÄúSetting expectations across academia and industry‚Äù.
He started writing the chapter at a Turing Way Book Dash event, based on an idea they had developed in advance of the event.
He responded to review comments and iteratively improved the chapter until the pull request was merged.
He is acknowledged in the Contributors table with üëÄ (

) emojis.
He is also named as an author on the latest release of the book.

community with the in-kind support of their funders and organisation, we acknowledge each member individually and list their organisations as ‚ÄúCollaborating organisations‚Äù.
Such organisational supports are applicable when one or multiple members from a project or community collaborate to build resources in

.
These efforts are highly encouraged to ensure the sustainability of their resources that can benefit a much wider community.
